docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''President Asks Congress for Measures Against Frivolous Suits'' (news article, Jan. 17):
docs.abstract: Ramesh Chellaton letter blames out-of-control jury awards for higher medical malpractice insurance costs and high costs for consumers (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''President Asks Congress for Measures Against Frivolous Suits'' (news article, Jan. 17):

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Double taxation,'' President Bush said in introducing his proposal to end the personal tax on dividends, ''is bad for our economy. Double taxation is wrong.'' Corporate dividends, however, are not the only kind of income that is taxed twice. Other taxes create a double, triple or even quintuple burden. And unlike the double taxation of dividends, which mainly affects the wealthy, the burden of other forms of multiple taxation -- sales taxes, import taxes, payroll taxes, among others -- often falls most heavily on poorer Americans.

headline.main: Doubling Up Of Taxation Isn't Limited To Dividends

docs.snippet: ''Double taxation,'' President Bush said in introducing his proposal to end the personal tax on dividends, ''is bad for our economy. Double taxation is wrong.''    Corporate dividends, however, are not the only kind of income that is taxed twice....

docs.lead_paragraph: ''My husband and I agreed we wouldn't tell anyone my diagnosis,'' the patient told me. Recently, she had tested positive for the gene associated with Huntington's disease. For several years, she had debated whether to be tested. Her mother, after all, had died of the disease, developing psychosis and slowly losing her bodily control and her mind. And because of Huntington's hereditary nature, the daughter had a 50 percent chance of carrying the gene herself.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert Klitzman article discusses complex issues raised by genetic testing in light of his experiences with patient who has tested postive for gene associated with Huntingon's disease, fatal brain disorder; notes even proposed laws to protect privacy of such data will not protect people from problems that emerge in personal relationships; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Medical Society of New Jersey, which represents thousands of doctors, has decided to support the doctors' work stoppage to protest soaring malpractice insurance rates. The organization's board unanimously approved a resolution on Sunday backing the doctors and pledging to provide legal and public relations assistance. The medical society has also called on the state's doctors to march on the capital on Feb. 4, the day that Gov. James E. McGreevey will present his budget to a joint session of the State Legislature. ''Doctors are going to go out on Feb. 3, and they're going to stay out until a reform package is adopted,'' said Robert J. Conroy, the organization's general counsel.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Support For Doctors' Job Action

docs.abstract: Medical Society of New Jersey, which represents thousands of doctors, will support doctors' work stoppage to protest soaring malpractice rates; strike is set for Feb 3 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush's take on medical malpractice (news article, Jan. 17) is at best a Band-Aid. While some blame lawyers and frivolous litigation for skyrocketing premiums, numerous studies indicate that insurance industry investment earnings or lack of them actually drive premiums. Indeed, total jury awards have not appreciably changed on a year-to-year industrywide basis. Without insurance reform aimed at evaluating true risk, the premium crisis will continue. Just as safe drivers are rewarded, so should safe and careful physicians. The public, too, must understand that a poor outcome does not always equate to malpractice.
docs.abstract: Dr Jonathan Heiliczer letter says Pres Bush's take on medical malpractice is Band-Aid at best (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush has proposed measures to deal with what he calls ''frivolous'' claims against doctors (news article, Jan. 17). In fact, the president's proposals would affect only meritorious claims.
docs.abstract: Stephen Gillers letter points out that Pres Bush's proposals to limit malpractice suits against doctors would affect only meritorious claims (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    President Bush has proposed measures to deal with what he calls ''frivolous'' claims against doctors (news article, Jan. 17). In fact, the president's proposals would affect only meritorious claims.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Malpractice Insurance Crisis'' (editorial, Jan. 17): There are two basic factors that have fueled the recurring malpractice insurance crisis since the 1970's. One is a societal delusion shared by most doctors that flawless medical practice is feasible and the expected standard. Doctors are destined to make unavoidable errors, which are not due to negligence.
docs.abstract: Dr Jack Hasson letter says that fueling malpractice insurance crisis since 1970's is societal delusion that flawless medical practice is possible, as well as fact that only deep pocket to compensate for injury is doctors' liability insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Doctors are making tremendous strides treating cystic fibrosis, the most common life-shortening genetic disease among Caucasians (Personal Health, ''Scientists Plot Tactics to Outmaneuver Cystic Fibrosis Gene,'' Jan. 14).
docs.abstract: Hadassah president Bonnie Lipton letter on Jan 14 article urges Congress to bar insurance and employment discrimination on basis of predictive genetic information to spur more Americans to be tested for genetic mutations linked to cystic fibrosis and other life-threatening genetic diseases

docs.lead_paragraph: IN most apartment buildings, the most recognizable person is the man or woman referred to as ''the super.'' The traditional image evoked by those words is that of a tool-toting jack of all trades who fixes leaks, changes light bulbs, hauls out the trash and kick-starts a quirky furnace. Today, however, superintendents -- particularly those in the larger buildings -- need a broader array of technical, mechanical, managerial and social skills. It stands to reason, then, that considerable effort should go into finding an effective superintendent.
docs.abstract: Jay Romano Your Home column describes job of building superintendent in New York; position has expanded beyond traditional maintenance responsibilities to include being ambassador of building, dealing with residents in constructive way; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To slow the growth of Medicare, an influential federal advisory panel will soon recommend that Congress freeze payments to nursing homes and home care agencies and reduce the cost-of-living allowance that hospitals are scheduled to receive next year. Republicans in Congress and Bush administration officials welcomed the proposals, saying they would save money for taxpayers and the Medicare trust fund. But health care providers expressed alarm, saying the proposals could reduce access to care for millions of the elderly and disabled.

headline.main: Commission to Urge Freezing Some Medicare Payments

docs.abstract: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, influential federal advisory panel, will recommend that Congress freeze payments to nursing homes and home care agencies and reduce cost-of-living allowance that hospitals are scheduled to receive next year, in order to slow growth of Medicare; Republicans in Congress and Bush administration officials welcome proposals, saying they would save money for taxpayers and Medicare trust fund; health care providers express alarm; panel will also recommend 2.5 percent increase in Medicare payments to doctors next year; payments to doctors were cut 5.4 percent last year, and futher cut of 4.4 percent is scheduled to take effect Mar 1; regarding proposed freeze on payments to nursing homes and home care agencies, many of 17 commissioners on panel say Medicare has no obligation to make up for underpayments by other insurers, like Medicaid (M)
docs.snippet: To slow the growth of Medicare, an influential federal advisory panel will soon recommend that Congress freeze payments to nursing homes and home care agencies and reduce the cost-of-living allowance that hospitals are scheduled to receive next year....
